item.title: Staying alive: world leaders who have had to prove they haven't died - The Guardian
item.description:
Staying alive: world leaders who have had to prove they haven't died  The Guardian

It is one of the stranger occupational hazards for world leaders: that at some point in their career they may have to deny reports of their own death. Just one day after the Nigerian president Muhammadu Buhari denied claims he had died and been replaced by a Sudanese impostor “clone”, another world leader has been forced to address rumours of his demise. Ali Bongo, the president of Gabon, made his first appearance on Monday since falling ill nearly six weeks ago. item.title: Gabon's Bongo headed to Morocco to continue recovery: wife - Reuters
item.description:
Gabon's Bongo headed to Morocco to continue recovery: wife  Reuters

Gabon's President Ali Bongo will leave Saudi Arabia, where he was hospitalized last month after suffering a stroke, to continue treatment in Morocco, his wife said on Tuesday. Bongo has not been seen in public since being admitted to hospital during a conference on Oct. 24. Gabon's top court ruled earlier this month that the vice president would chair the cabinet in Bongo's absence. In a post on her Facebook page, Sylvia Bongo wrote that her husband's health had improved significantly and that he would travel to Rabat on Wednesday. item.title: Gabon opposition rejects president's call for talks to ease tensions - Reuters
item.description:
Gabon opposition rejects president's call for talks to ease tensions  Reuters

LIBREVILLE (Reuters) - Gabonese President Ali Bongo has offered to hold talks with opposition parties in an apparent bid to ease tensions over his contested re-election last year, but his main political rival swiftly rejected the call for dialogue. Responding to a presidency statement issued late on Friday, opposition leader Jean Ping branded the proposal for talks starting on March 28 as a "masquerade" and said he would not participate. item.title: As Africa Cup of Nations Enters Elimination Phase, Many Fans Stay Home - VOA News
item.description:
As Africa Cup of Nations Enters Elimination Phase, Many Fans Stay Home  VOA News

The Africa Cup of Nations enters the elimination phase Saturday in Gabon as eight of the 16 football (soccer) teams that started the tournament compete for the four places in the semi-finals. Hundreds of secondary school students lined up at the government high school in the center of Libreville to receive entry tickets for AFCON matches. item.title: Equatorial Guinea leader's son on trial in France in absentia - Reuters
item.description:
Equatorial Guinea leader's son on trial in France in absentia  Reuters

PARIS (Reuters) - The son of Equatorial Guinea's president went on trial on Monday in his absence in Paris on charges of using money plundered from his country to buy Parisian luxury properties and exotic cars. Teodorin Obiang, eldest son of President Teodoro Obiang and a vice-president himself, denies charges of laundering embezzled public funds, for which he risks a sentence of 10 years in jail and huge fines if convicted. item.title: Gabon's Stade Omar Bongo casts a shadow as the Africa Cup of Nations gets into full swing - The Independent
item.description:
Gabon's Stade Omar Bongo casts a shadow as the Africa Cup of Nations gets into full swing  The Independent

In the weeds, a goat bleats. In the ditch, a naked man washes himself. In a wired-off compound, diggers sit idle. And at the centre of it all is the Stade Omar Bongo, concrete supports reaching into the humid grey sky. There is a grass pitch and there are not merely goals in place but practice nets have been set up; teams will train here. This should have been the centrepiece of Gabon’s second Cup of Nations in five years, the president Ali Bongo’s tribute to his father, whom he succeeded after his death in 2009. item.title: Political unrest in Gabon casts shadow over 2017 Africa Cup of Nations draw - The Guardian
item.description:
Political unrest in Gabon casts shadow over 2017 Africa Cup of Nations draw  The Guardian

No news, they say, is good news. Either that or it’s the result of a government blackout. The draw for the Africa Cup of Nations will be held in Libreville, Gabon, on Wednesday but yet again the buildup to a tournament has been dominated by doubts over where it will be staged as the aftershocks of Gabonese presidential elections continue to be reverberate. At the moment it seems the tournament will go ahead in Gabon, beginning on 14 January, but no one is confident. Even by the standards of the Cup of Nations, the 2017 edition has seemed ill-starred. item.title: Health of Gabon's hospitalized leader has greatly improved: presidency - Reuters
item.description:
Health of Gabon's hospitalized leader has greatly improved: presidency  Reuters

The health of Gabon's President Ali Ben Bongo has greatly improved and he is recovering his physical abilities, his office said on Sunday, after sources said last month he suffered a stroke. Bongo was admitted to hospital on Oct. 24 in Saudi Arabia after the stroke, the sources said, though Gabonese authorities said he was merely suffering from fatigue. One TV station in Gabon has been banned for reporting he had died. item.title: Gabon VP takes over cabinet amid President Bongo's illness - Reuters
item.description:
Gabon VP takes over cabinet amid President Bongo's illness  Reuters

Gabon's top court has ruled that the vice president will chair the cabinet in the absence of President Ali Bongo, who remains in hospital in Saudi Arabia after suffering a stroke last month. The decision, announced by the constitutional court on Wednesday, is the first move to fill the vacuum left after Bongo was admitted to hospital during a conference on Oct. 24. Bongo has not been seen in public since and his state of health is unknown. The government said he suffered a bout of fatigue and is recovering, but sources told Reuters that he had a stroke. item.description:
Hospitalised Gabon leader Ali Bongo greatly improved: presidency  Al Jazeera English

The health of Gabon's President Ali Bongo has "greatly improved" after the 59-year-old was hospitalised as a result of discomfort and "persistent vertigo", according to the presidency. item.description:
Gabon: Government Says President Recovering in Saudi Arabia  VOA News

The government of Gabon says President Ali Bongo Ondimba is recovering from an undisclosed illness in Saudi Arabia. item.title: Gabon heads to the polls to elect members of parliament - Al Jazeera English
item.description:
Gabon heads to the polls to elect members of parliament  Al Jazeera English

People in Gabon are voting in a long-delayed legislative and municipal polls, the first to be held since a presidential election two years ago marred by deadly violence and fraud allegations. Most polling stations in the capital Libreville opened at 8:00 am local time (0700 GMT) under grey skies and light rain on Saturday. Posters around Libreville were seen asking the country's 680,000 voters to turn up to elect 143 new MPs as well as other local officials. item.title: Gabon ruling party claims election win - Al Jazeera English
item.description:
Gabon ruling party claims election win  Al Jazeera English

President Ali Bongo's ruling Gabonese Democratic Party (PDG) has won a legislative election by a landslide in the first round, the presidency said. "We have observed what looks like a landslide in favour of the [ruling] majority," presidential spokesman Ike Ngouoni said on Sunday, citing results posted publicly at voting stations. He said the PDG had won 80 of the 143 seats in the national parliament. Ngouoni said turnout was "relatively weak". item.title: Gabon accuses Veolia of causing severe pollution - Financial Times
item.description:
Gabon accuses Veolia of causing severe pollution  Financial Times

The government of Gabon has stepped up its feud with Veolia, accusing the French water, waste management and energy group of causing widespread “severe pollution” at several operating sites in the central African nation. Last month, the Gabon government seized 35 sites operated by Veolia through its Gabonese subsidiary. item.description:
New TV show tells of capture of Gabon ivory smuggling gang  The Independent

The extraordinary story of how the Gabonese wildlife service managed to capture the biggest ivory smuggling ring in the country’s history has been revealed by a new document. item.title: 2 Danish Journalists Violently Attacked in Gabon - VOA News
item.description:
2 Danish Journalists Violently Attacked in Gabon  VOA News

A man stabbed two Danish journalists in Gabon's capital, declaring it was in retaliation for U.S. attacks against Muslims and leaving one reporter in serious condition, Gabon's defense minister said. The attack Saturday occurred while the journalists were shopping at an artisanal market, a site popular with tourists. It is the first of its kind in this West African country where Muslims and Christians coexist peacefully.
